posts.cooked: are these imports outdated and are there new ones to use?

posts.name: Isaac Thoman
posts.cooked:
Perhaps. In what context are you using PIDOutput?

It looks like the PIDController import line can be replaced with the following: import edu.wpi.first.math.controller.PIDController;

I am very new to PID control and am trying to use the navx2 example code to make our robot which is a tank drive be able to auto rotate to an  angle this is the example code provided by naxx2 navxmxp/roborio/java/navXMXP_Java_RotateToAngle_Tank/src/org/usfirst/frc/team2465/robot/Robot.java at master · kauailabs/navxmxp · GitHub I believe some of these imports are outdated and want to know if the PIDOutput has a newer import or got replaced.

posts.name: Isaac Thoman
posts.cooked:
Do you have working arcade tank drive code already? If so, I’d recommend following the current WPILib PID tutorial, passing in the angle of your NavX when you call the pid.calculate() method. You could then add the output of the PID controller to your drive base’s rotational output.

Be sure to read the Setting Continuous Input section as well since you’re working with angles.

WPILib supports PID control of mechanisms through the PIDController class ( Java, C++, Python). This class handles the feedback loop calculation for the user, as well as offering methods for return...

link_counts.title: PID Control in WPILib — FIRST Robotics Competition documentation

posts.cooked: Alright I will check it out thank you.
This code is extremely outdated - the PID class/es were completely refactored in 2020. Reference the updated documentation/examples.
is there like any resources I can use to learn gyro programming for example videos or example code or gyro templates?
Gyroscopes - Software — FIRST Robotics Competition documentation has info about using gyros in general, and there’s a small section a bit earlier that’s navx-specific.
